body:
Hi @riccardosamperna ,

I'm not sure what pre and post-contrast images look like, but from the sound of it i'm not sure the MSE is appropriate for the image matching term (as the miccai model uses). It might be more appropriate to use CC (which is available in the losses file) or MI (which I could send you) depending on the images.

Can you post a screenshot of your images?

Thanks a lot for the hint about the loss, I am going to look into that.
Below you can find an example, the idea is to register the post-contrast image to the pre-contrast one. Currently I am using just a single breast to run a small experiment.

Pre-contrast
![pre-contrast](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6599726/62552337-c3f3ed80-b86d-11e9-9d3b-92496c9def3e.png)
Post-contrast
![post_contrast](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6599726/62552344-c6564780-b86d-11e9-8c21-8d6551980899.png)
Warped post-contrast
![warped](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6599726/62552351-c9513800-b86d-11e9-950f-489c84f67b94.png)
Deformation-field
![deformation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6599726/62552359-cbb39200-b86d-11e9-8482-595939866a7f.png)

While ultimately MI would likely be most robust, these images look like they might work with CC.
I would encourage you to try the CVPR voxelmorph with CC (and the CC hyper-parameter value) simply because we've tested CC for the CVPR model quite a bit and it seems to work well. If that works, it should be quite easy to switch to the MICCAI model.

I have already tried to switch to an NCC loss with the MICCAI network but I am having similar results as before. I will try the code from CVPR and I will keep you posted about any improvement. Thanks a lot for your reply.

ok, let me know -- remember that by trying NCC you should dramatically change the hyper-parameter. 
For our brain data, in the CVPR version, for example, if you use MSE you should use a regularization parameter of 0.01, but with CC then 1.0 is a good start. So you'd need to make some changes in the MICCAI version as well.

Also, from those images it's apparent that the deformations are very large and in some areas nearly discontinuous, so it feels like the spatial smoothness regularization isn't large enough.

When I tried the MICCAI version with NCC, I indeed made some changes to the hyperparameters (I used (1.0, 1.0) as loss weights) based on what I saw in the CVPR one but I was still getting large deformations. Currently I am testing the CVPR one with reg_param of 1.5 and it seems to be doing a much better job.

I have a question about the losses, I attached a txt file where you can see the values of the losses in ~150 epochs. It looks like that all the losses, both for training and validation, are not changing or have just small variations, is this behaviour normal? I have seen it in all runs I made so far, similar behaviour when I was using MSE loss.

[07082019T162303_log.txt](https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/files/3480346/07082019T162303_log.txt)

- if the CVPR version works and the MICCAI version does not with NCC, I think it just requires a better choice of hyper-parameters. Perhaps we'll work at providing specific guidance for MICCAI version with NCC (my first guess wouldn't beed to take lambda from 10 to 1000 while keeping image sigma the same, I think around 0.02).

- Because the batch size is usually only 1, we set the learning rate to be fairly small, and the losses will change seemingly little and very noisly. I would recommend avoiding looking at the losses numerically, it really tends to be misleading because we tend to try to make conclusions from any noisy pattern we see -- I'd recommend plotting them and trying to estimate the overall trend.

Dear Adrian,
I need to ask one thing Can i use Grad('l2') loss with MSE in MICCAI version ?
Because in MICCAI paper you use KL loss with MSE

@hfahad,

The MICCAI model gives you diffeomorphisms and probabilities -- which of these do you need, if any? If you want both, the KL loss is a clean thing to use, and this includes a smoothing factor since the KL term includes a graph laplacian. 

However, if all you desire are diffeomorphisms, then you could just avoid using the sampling layer that adds probabilities, and use Grad('l2') on the final displacement after diffeomorphisms. 

If you'd like to continue this discussion, though, please start a new github issue, to not distract from @riccardosamperna's questions.

> Because the batch size is usually only 1, we set the learning rate to be fairly small, and the losses will change seemingly little and very noisly. I would recommend avoiding looking at the losses numerically, it really tends to be misleading because we tend to try to make conclusions from any noisy pattern we see -- I'd recommend plotting them and trying to estimate the overall trend.

I followed your advice (plotted the csv) and I noticed that indeed the loss and the spatial transformer loss are going down, only the flow_loss has an up trend (_it can happen, as you pointed out in another issue_). Have you used any kind of learning rate decay strategy during training?

@riccardosamperna it's fine for some part of the loss to go up as long as the overall loss goes down.
I've tried learning rate decay before and it can help, but honestly having lr of 1e-4 does most of the job without any more fiddling usually needed.

I am already getting much better results compared to what I posted in the first place. A strong regularization of the deformation field helped in the CVPR network, soon I will try to see also what happens with the MICCAI version. Thanks for your replies and your support @adalca. For the moment I will close the issue, I will keep on posting here if I have any more questions.

Dear @adalca,
I am back with a somewhat unrelated question. The CVPR network I trained for my problem seems to be working now but I would like to investigate the problem of the negative Jacobians I read about in other posts and in your MICCAI paper. Have you checked the influence of this effect on the CVPR network? Can you share any code you used to actually calculate this effect?
